title: Curtis Enis
text:
Curtis Thomas Enis (born June 15, 1976) is a former American college and professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player who was a <a href="running%20back">running back</a> in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) for three seasons. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> for <a href="Penn%20State%20University">Penn State University</a>, and earned <a href="All-American">All-American</a> honors. Enis was a first-round pick in the <a href="1998%20NFL%20Draft">1998 NFL Draft</a>, and played professionally for the NFL's <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> and <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>. He was also a key player in Midway’s 1998 <a href="NFL%20Blitz">NFL Blitz</a>, often regarded as the best player in the game, rarely fumbling when using the spin move. 
Early years.
Enis was born in <a href="Union%20City%2C%20Ohio">Union City, Ohio</a>. He attended <a href="Mississinawa%20Valley%20High%20School">Mississinawa Valley High School</a> in Union City, where he was named a "<a href="Parade%20%28magazine%29">Parade</a>" magazine high school <a href="All-American">All-American</a>, and voted Ohio's <a href="Mr.%20Football%20Award%20%28Ohio%29">Mr. Football Award</a> by the <a href="Associated%20Press">Associated Press</a>. He was a three-time all-state selection at <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a>, and <a href="Most%20Valuable%20Player">Most Valuable Player</a> of the 1994 <a href="Big%2033%20Football%20Classic">Big 33 Football Classic</a>. He spent one year at <a href="The%20Kiski%20School">The Kiski School</a> in <a href="Saltsburg%2C%20Pennsylvania">Saltsburg, Pennsylvania</a>.
College career.
Enis attended Pennsylvania State University, where he majored in recreational management and played for coach <a href="Joe%20Paterno">Joe Paterno</a>'s <a href="Penn%20State%20Nittany%20Lions%20football">Penn State Nittany Lions football</a> team from 1995 to 1997. Following his junior season in 1997, he was recognized as a consensus first-team All-American.
His rushing stats at <a href="Penn%20State">Penn State</a> were:
Professional career.
Enis initially held out and ended up missing 26 days of training camp and 2 exhibition games after being drafted by the <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> with the 5th overall pick.
Enis made just one start before tearing a ligament in his left knee in November 1998. His career in Chicago was largely defined by struggling to stay on the field as a result of injuries, and by poor production when he did play. By 2000, Enis had been supplanted by <a href="James%20Allen%20%28running%20back%29">James Allen</a> and was being utilized as a FB. In three years, he played 36 games, accumulating 1,497 rushing yards and 4 touchdowns.
In 2001, at the age of 24, Enis signed a one-year deal with the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>, but a degenerative condition in his left knee forced him into retirement.
Post-playing career.
After retiring, Enis was hired by ABInBev as an Operation Manager.
Enis was the head football coach at <a href="Bradford%20High%20School%20%28Ohio%29">Bradford High School</a> in <a href="Bradford%2C%20Ohio">Bradford</a>, <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a> from 2010 to 2013. Enis was the Ohio High School Athletic Association (OHSAA) Division VI Coach of the Year in 2010.
 He resigned from that position in August 2014.
